paragraphs.text: This article changed my perspective. Thank you for reminding us to be empathetic and understanding of other peoples’ experiences.

2ac0e167ebca.title: There’s a bus service that runs from Sheffield railway station, almost past my house, and on out…

paragraphs.text: There’s a bus service that runs from Sheffield railway station, almost past my house, and on out into the Derbyshire Peak District to the small town of Bakewell. Going one way or the other the bus diverts to call at Chatsworth House, a stately home (actually, a palace….). Somehow that trip to Chatsworth has got onto young Chinese students’ tourist…

54a0b5352161.title: We can confess that in Paris, we don’t like tourists.

paragraphs.text: We can confess that in Paris, we don’t like tourists. Tourists in large groups, to be precise. But the fact is, we appreciate that they want to see our city, but they are a major problem : too many coaches inside our streets, we can’t access our museums and Grands Magasins anymore, and the worst is : they are only here to take pictures of all the…
paragraphs.name: da3c

content.subtitle: But we like to meet travellers : people curious about local life, that we are always ready to help.

paragraphs.text: No, it isn’t. Definitely goes both ways. Which is why I think it’s so important for an insular, 92% ethnically homogenous nation like China to have it’s people travel outside its own borders, even if in large packs.

virtuals.subtitle: I’ve met a (very) few nice mainland Chinese when travelling, I’ve also experienced the extremely loud, extremely rude, line cutting…

90a6750f7105.title: I do wonder what the reaction would be if this was written from the perspective of a white person.

paragraphs.text: I do wonder what the reaction would be if this was written from the perspective of a white person. “Oh you should excuse them when they break local customs, offend people, are rude and entitled; it is just what they are used to at home.” Would that fly?

paragraphs.text: Great article, Panpan Wang. Brought lots of chuckles. Btw, mainland Chinese tourists aren’t the only groups who are looked down upon by others. Heck, having your whole people labeled by derogatory terms like gweilo or guizi or ang mo is not exactly respectful now, is it?

I love this article. I’m an American (born and raised in Oakland, CA) living in Zagreb, Croatia while I teach at the university for a semester, and I’ve been amazed at the number of Chinese tour groups that have been here ever since I arrived in December, when it was very, very cold. (Other wimpier cultures — Americans, French, Germans — are only…

69295535469c.title: Sure, but the PRC isn’t exactly Easter Island.

paragraphs.text: Sure, but the PRC isn’t exactly Easter Island. “As the most populous country in the world and third largest in area, China also has the largest number of neighbours (14) sharing its 22,000km land borders namely: North Korea, Russia, Mongolia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, Nepal, Bhutan, Myanmar, Laos and Vietnam.…
paragraphs.name: d2bb

paragraphs.text: Thank you for writing this. As someone who lived in China and has seen these groups in China as well, I completely agree with you that we need to see the Chinese in context of their recent history and the times they grew up in. Living through the Great Depression and Cultural Revolution would irrevocably change anyone. We are all people shaped by our…

6670e55bc856.title: I also wonder the same things.

paragraphs.text: I also wonder the same things. My intention is not to excuse poor behavior. My intention is to help increase understanding and perspective. Frankly, being someone who is often embarrassed by the poor behavior of some/many Chinese tour groups, this essay as more catharsis for myself in being less judgmental to my own people. Thanks for sharing your perspective, Michael.

Parisians, Vancouverites, and San Franciscans may feel similarly. But Louis Vitton, Gucci and Apple (AAPL: 143.34) don’t seem to care. I’ve talked to many local businesses all over the world who complain about the Chinese, but who readily accept their cash.
Anyway, thanks for writing and sharing this amazing story, it changed our view on Chinese tourists :)
